facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2271 of 1970 was filed by certificate from the judgment and order dated September 23, 1970 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Appeal No. 31 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2271 of 1970. Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated September 23, 1970 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court at Hyderabad in Writ Appeal No. 31 of 1970. S. Desai, Naunit Lal and M. N. Shroff, for the appella

facts.text: State Government referred certain disputes to the Industrial Tribunal Andhra Pradesh, Hyderabad by order dated July 25, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated July 25, 1968. the State, Government referred to the Industrial Tribunal Andhra Pradesh, Hyderabad, for adjudication certain disputes. The appellant raised a preliminary objection that in respect of the items companyered by the present reference, there was a previous award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957 passed by the Tribunal on September 26, 1958.

facts.text: There was a previous award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957 passed by the Tribunal on September 26, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant raised a preliminary objection that in respect of the items companyered by the present reference, there was a previous award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957 passed by the Tribunal on September 26, 1958. As the said award had number been terminated, the present reference by the State Government on July 25, 1968, was incompetent.

facts.text: The previous award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957 was published in the State Gazette on October 30, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbercontroversy that there was a previous award in I.D. No. 20 of 1967 dated September 26, 1958. This award was published in the State Gazette on October 30, 1958. Under the said award, various benefits were given to the staff, apart from fixing basic wages for different categories.

facts.text: Thursday hydra Industries Staff Union submitted a charter of demands to the management on March 8, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: On March 8, 1968, the Thursday hydra Industries Staff Union submitted a charter of demands to the management to be im- mediately companyplied with. The first and the second demands related to categorization and scales of pay and dearness allowance respectively.

facts.text: The union sent a copy of the resolution passed by its general body on April 5, 1968 to the appellant on April 6, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The union desired the management to companysider the demands and intimate the union regarding the action taken on or before March 30, 1968. On 6th April, 1968, the union sent to the appellant a companyy of the resolution passed by its general body on April 5, 1968.

facts.text: Workmen went on strike from April 15, 1968 to April 30, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The resolution regretted the inaction of the management in respect of the demands made on March 8, 1968 and also intimated that the workmen will go on an indefinite strike front April 15, 1968. Accordingly the workmen were on strike from April 15, 1968 to April 30, 1968.

facts.text: Assistant Labour Commissioner, Kurnool held conciliation proceedings on April 30, 1968 and an agreement was arrived at.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly the workmen were on strike from April 15, 1968 to April 30, 1968. The Assistant Labour Commissioner, Kurnool, held companyciliation proceedings on April 30, 1968 and an agreement was arrived at. One of the terms of the, agreement was that the general demands of the staff union will be taken up in companyciliation.

facts.text: Conciliation Officer made a report on June 24, 1968 to the Government that conciliation was not possible.

anchor.surface_text: The Conciliation Officer made a report on June 24, 1968, to the Government that companyciliation was number possible. The State Government, after receipt of this report, passed an order on July 25, 1968, referring the dispute for adjudication.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal by its award dated October 31, 1969 upheld the objection of the company and held that the award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957 had not been terminated and the reference was incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal by its award dated October 31, 1969 upheld the objection of the companypany and hold that the award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957 bad number been terminated. In companysequence, the Tribunal held that the reference was incompetent.

facts.text: Workmen challenged the Tribunal's award in Writ Petition No. 4186 of 1969 before the Andhra Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen challenged the award in Writ Petition No. 4186 of 1969 before the Andhra Pradesh High Court. The learned single Judge, who dealt with the said Writ Petition, by his judgment and order dated December 8, 1969, dismissed the Writ Petition and agreed with the view of the Tribunal that the award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957 had number been terminated and hence the present reference by the State Government was incompetent.

facts.text: Single Judge of AP High Court dismissed Writ Petition No. 4186 of 1969 on December 8, 1969, agreeing that previous award not terminated.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single Judge, who dealt with the said Writ Petition, by his judgment and order dated December 8, 1969, dismissed the Writ Petition and agreed with the view of the Tribunal that the award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957 had number been terminated and hence the present reference by the State Government was incompetent.

facts.text: Division Bench of AP High Court in Writ Appeal No. 31 of 1970 held that previous award had been terminated and reference competent.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the workmen, the Division Bench in Writ Appeal No. 31 of 1970, however, took a companytrary view and held that the, previous award had been terminated. In this view, the learned Judges held that the present reference was companypetent and directed the Industrial Tribunal to dispose of the reference on merits.

facts.text: Appellant raised preliminary objection that previous award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957 not terminated, so reference incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant raised a preliminary objection that in respect of the items companyered by the present reference, there was a previous award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957 passed by the Tribunal on September 26, 1958. As the said award had number been terminated, the present reference by the State Government on July 25, 1968, was incompetent.

facts.text: Workmen contended before Tribunal that previous award had been terminated according to law.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen, on the other hand,, companytended before the Tribunal that the previous award had been terminated according to law and, therefore, there was numberbar to the State Government making the present reference.

facts.text: No notice terminating previous award given by management as on March 8, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: In the, case before us, when the charter of demands was pre- sented to the management by the union on March 8, 1968, admittedly the latter had number given any numberice, as companytemplated under section 19 6  of the Act.

facts.text: Charter of demands referred to all matters covered by previous award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It is also number in dispute that the said charter of demands referred to all the matters companyered by the previous award in 1. D, No. 20 of 1957. Under these circumstances, the question arises whether the present reference dated July 25, 1968, is companypetent.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that previous award not terminated, reference incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: We are number inclined to agree with the view of the Division Bench that there has been a termination of the award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957. If so, the Industrial Tribunal as well as the learned single Judge were right in holding that the present reference dated July 25,,1968, is incompetent.

facts.text: Division Bench relied on charter of demands on March 8, 1968 as terminating previous award.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench has also held that numbernotice. terminating the previous award, as required by section 19 6  of the Act, was given when the charter of demands was submitted to the management on March 8, 1968.

facts.text: Conciliation Officer in report dated June 24, 1968 stated management not inclined to consider demands as previous award not terminated.

anchor.surface_text: But it is to be numbered that in the report dated June 24. 1968, the Conciliation Officer had clearly stated that with regard to the demand for categorisation and scales of pay, the management were number inclined to companysider the same, as they had been fixed by the award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957 and that the said award had number been terminated so far.

facts.text: Award under section 17A becomes enforceable 30 days after publication on October 30, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The previous award in I. D. No. 20 of 1957 member 26, 1958 and was published in the State 30, 1958. Under section 17A, the said award on the expiry of 30 days from October 30, 1958, location under section 17.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside judgment of Division Bench in Writ Appeal No. 31 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the judgment and order of the High Court in Writ Appeal No. 31 of 1970 are set aside and. the appeal.

Under section 19, sub-section 3 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, hereinafter to be referred to as the Act , an award is operative, subject to the provisions of the said section, for a period of one year from the date on which the award becomes enforceable under section 17A.

concepts.interpretation: An award is operative for a period of one year from the date it becomes enforceable under section 17A.

concepts.interpretation: Award continues to be binding after expiry of one year until two months elapse from notice by any party intimating intention to terminate.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant raised a preliminary objection that in respect of the items referred by the present reference, there was a previous award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957 passed by the Tribunal on September 26, 1958. As the said award had not been terminated, the present reference by the State Government on July 25, 1968, was incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 19, sub-section (3) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, hereinafter to be referred to as the Act, an award is operative... Sub-section (6) of section 19 provides that, notwithstanding the expiry of the period of operation under subsection (3), the award shall continue to be binding on the parties until a period of two months has elapsed from the date on which notice is given

arguments.claim: Management had not given any notice under s.19(6) when charter presented on Mar 8, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, when the charter of demands was presented to the management by the union on March 8, 1968, admittedly the latter had not given any notice, as contemplated under section 19(6) of the Act.

arguments.claim: Division Bench approach erroneous; must establish point of time of termination under s.19(6), charter on Mar 8 not proper termination.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the question that should have been tackled was whether on March 8, 1968, when the charter of demands was submitted, there has been a proper termination of the previous award, as required under section 19(6).

arguments.claim: Workmen going on strike does not satisfy requirement under s.19(6).

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the workmen went on a strike subsequently may indicate that they are dissatisfied with the refusal of the management to accede to their demands. But that will not satisfy the requirement under section 19(6).

arguments.claim: Management participation in conciliation proceedings does not indicate termination under s.19(6).

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the appellant participated in the conciliation proceedings held by the Conciliation Officer, which is also on subsequent date, is also of no importance. When a strike is on, it is obligatory on the part of the Conciliation Officer to initiate conciliation proceedings

arguments.claim: Per Bangalore Woollen, termination notice must be fixed with reference to particular date to express clear intention; charter lacks this.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held in Management of Bangalore Woollen, Cotton Silk Mills Co. Ltd. case that regarding the termination of an award, it must be fixed with reference to a particular date so as to enable a court to come to the conclusion that the party giving that intimation has expressed its intention to terminate the award.

arguments.claim: Even assuming charter terminated award on Mar 8, it continues for further 2 months under s.19(6); but strike before expiry indicates otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: Even assuming that by the charter of demands on March 8, 1968, the award was terminated, nevertheless, it will continue to be in force, for a further period of two months from that date under section 19(6).

holdings.text: The present reference dated July 25, 1968 is incompetent because the previous award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957 had not been terminated under section 19(6) of the Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are number inclined to agree with the view of the Division Bench that there has been a termination of the award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957. If so, the Industrial Tribunal as well as the learned single Judge were right in holding that the present reference dated July 25,,1968, is incompetent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Previous award continues binding absent proper notice under s.19(6); no valid termination by charter of demands, strike, or conciliation; applies statutory provisions and Bangalore Woollen precedent.

holdings.text: There was no proper termination of the previous award on March 8, 1968 when the charter of demands was submitted, as required under section 19(6).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the question that should have been tackled was whether on March 8, 1968, when the charter of demands was submitted, there has be-en a proper termination of the previous award, as required under section 19 6 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Division Bench erred by not pinpointing termination time; management gave no notice, and charter lacks specificity required by s.19(6) and precedent.

holdings.text: The serving of a charter of demands inconsistent with the previous award does not satisfy the requirement of notice under section 19(6) to terminate the award.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ramamurthi, learned companynsel for some of the workmen, pointed out that the serving of a charter of demands clearly shows that the union had terminated the award. In our opinion, this companytention cannot be accepted, because it does number satisfy the requirement of section 19 6 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charter does not fix termination to a particular date, essential per Bangalore Woollen for reckoning two-month period; no clear intention expressed.

holdings.text: The workmen going on strike does not satisfy the requirement under section 19(6) for termination of the previous award.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the workmen went on a strike subsequently may indicate that they are dissatisfied with the refusal of the management to accede to their demands. But that will number satisfy the requirement under section 19 6 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strike indicates dissatisfaction but not formal notice intimating intention to terminate as mandated by s.19(6).

holdings.text: The management participating in conciliation proceedings does not indicate termination of the previous award under section 19(6).

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the appellant partici- pated in the companyciliation proceedings held by the Conciliation Officer, which is also on subsequent date, is also of numberimportance. When a strike is on, it is obligatory on the part of the Conciliation Officer to initiate companyciliation proceedings

holdings.reasoning_summary: Participation obligatory during strike; Conciliation Officer's report confirms management stance that award not terminated.

holdings.text: Notice terminating an award under section 19(6) must be fixed with reference to a particular date to clearly express intention to terminate.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held in Management of Bangalore Woollen, Cotton Silk Mills Co. Ltd.  1  case that regarding the termination of an award, it must be fixed with reference to a particular date so as to enable a companyrt to companye to the companyclusion that the party giving that intimation has expressed its intention to terminate the award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows and applies Bangalore Woollen precedent requiring certainty for two-month reckoning period; no particular form but specificity essential.

holdings.text: Even assuming the charter of demands terminated the award on March 8, 1968, it continues binding for two months under section 19(6), rendering the reference incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: Even assuming that by the charter of demands on March 8, 1968, the award was terminated, nevertheless, it will companytinue to be in force, for a further period of two months from that date under section 19 6 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical application of s.19(6); strike before two months expiry inconsistent with termination claim.

holdings.text: The judgment and order of the Division Bench in Writ Appeal No. 31 of 1970 is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the judgment and order of the High Court in Writ Appeal No. 31 of 1970 are set aside and. the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Flows from holding that Division Bench erred on termination and competency.

edges.explanation: c10 even if terminated on Mar 8 continues 2 months supports h2 no proper termination timing
The holding of no proper termination on March 8 is grounded in the concept requiring clear notice with specific date, as referenced in the requirement under section 19(6).
The holding that inconsistent charter does not satisfy notice requirement is grounded in the concept of clear intention to terminate with specific date.
The concept of requiring clear notice with specific date addresses the issue of proper termination on a specific date when charter was submitted.
The concept requiring clear intention with specific date addresses whether inconsistent charter indicates such intention for termination.
Concept grounds the specific holding of incompetency
Concept of incompetency due to non-termination addresses the issue of reference competency

Section 19(3) defines the minimum one-year operative period for awards from enforceability under 17A, which grounds the holding's reliance on non-termination under 19(6) to deem the new reference incompetent.
Section 19(3)'s rule on award operativity directly addresses the issue of competence of a new reference during that period.

anchor.surface_text: We are number inclined to agree with the view of the Division Bench that there has been a termination of the award in I.D. No. 20 of 1957. If so, the Industrial Tribunal as well as the learned single Judge were right in holding that the present reference dated July 25,,1968, is incompetent.
In the result, the judgment and order of the High Court in Writ Appeal No. 31 of 1970 are set aside and. the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the question that should have been tackled was whether on March 8, 1968, when the charter of demands was submitted, there has be-en a proper termination of the previous award, as required under section 19 6 .
In the result, the judgment and order of the High Court in Writ Appeal No. 31 of 1970 are set aside and. the appeal.
rty giving that intimation has expressed its intention to terminate the award. Such certainty rega

edges.explanation: The holding states that serving a charter of demands inconsistent with the award does not satisfy the notice requirement under section 19(6), directly addressing the issue of whether such a charter indicates intention to terminate.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ramamurthi, learned companynsel for some of the workmen, pointed out that the serving of a charter of demands clearly shows that the union had terminated the award. In our opinion, this companytention cannot be accepted, because it does number satisfy the requirement of section 19 6 .
In the result, the judgment and order of the High Court in Writ Appeal No. 31 of 1970 are set aside and. the appeal.

The fact that the workmen went on a strike subsequently may indicate that they are dissatisfied with the refusal of the management to accede to their demands. But that will number satisfy the requirement under section 19 6 .
In the result, the judgment and order of the High Court in Writ Appeal No. 31 of 1970 are set aside and. the appeal.

The fact that the appellant partici- pated in the companyciliation proceedings held by the Conciliation Officer, which is also on subsequent date, is also of numberimportance. When a strike is on, it is obligatory on the part of the Conciliation Officer to initiate companyciliation proceedings
In the result, the judgment and order of the High Court in Writ Appeal No. 31 of 1970 are set aside and. the appeal.
